\begin{align*}
&\text{"Divide"} \\
&555\\
&/5\\
&=1110\\
/5\\
&=226\\
/5\\
&=45\\
/5\\
&=9\\
/5\\
&=1\;R\,4\\
/5\\
&=0\; R\; 4\\
\end{align*}Now put powers of five starting from LSB i.e., \$1 * 5^0=1,\; 2*5^1=10,\; 1*5^2=25,\; 4*5^3=500,\; 0*5^4=0.\$Then writing them together results \[10\;10100\]Hence option C is correct . ost_step.2: And now let's simplify it further using our knowledge about powers of five;$$\begin{aligned} & (2 \times 5^4) + (3 \times 5^3) + (1 \times 5^1)\\ &= (2 \times 625) + (3 \times 125) + (1 \times 5)\\ &=(1250)+(375)+(5)\\ &=\underline{(1630)}\end{aligned}$$Therefore,$555_{10}=1630_5.$ That was easy!The answer is: 1630_5.

ost_step.1: To convert a decimal number to another base, repeatedly divide it by the desired base until you get a quotient less than or equal to zero. For each division, note the remainders as digits starting from bottom upwards when reading backward.

direct_answer.text:
To express $555_{10}$ in base $5$, let us start dividing successively by five till we reach one digit left. Here are the steps:  
\begin{align*}   
&555 \,/\, 5=    &111 \\[0pt]    
&111 \,/\, 5=&  &22 &(\text{with remainder}~1)\\[0pt]     
&22 \,/\, 5=&  &\text{$0$}&\cdot5+\text{R}2\\[0pt]      
&2 \,/\, 5 &= &0& (\text{we stopped since now our new dividend }<5 )\\         
\end{align*}             Now read backwards the results obtained above ($221$) so $555_{10}=221_5$. Note how here I wrote 'readings backwards', because while going through divisions first column was written under second, etc., but writing out answers starts form last nonzero row to first nonzero. ost_step.1: Combining those bits into groups of three gets us  10 001  010 11. Each group represents powers of five based on position starting from rightmost digit as exponent zero; hence you need one left shift each time so it becomes  1024   8    5     2. And when converted back using decimal notation results in  2*1024 + 0 * 8 + 2 * 5 + 1 * 2= 2048 + 0 + 10 + 2= 2060 . That result converts directly from power representation without having to multiply out resulting product because doing multiplication would require converting every bit value again giving rise to error due to loss of precision during intermediate calculations such as division etc.. direct_answer.text:
To express $555_{10}$ in base $5$, let's follow through with the conversion steps provided in your hint using repeated division method. Initially, divide $555$ by $5$:

$$555=5\times111+0.$$
This tells us our first base five digit is '0'. Now take the quotient '$111$', repeat the process again:

$$111=5\times22+1.$$
So now we append a second base five digit - one ('1'). Repeat once more with the new dividend '$22':

$$22=5\times4+2.$$
And finally add the third digit – two ('2') onto our representation. As no further calculations are needed because the last quotient "$4" is notably smaller than our chosen base "$5$," indicating completion of conversions. Reading the obtained bases backwards yields the original numeral represented in Base Five i.e., $555_{10}=1210_5.$ Hence the solution results in $\boxed{1210_5}$.
